Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Combining Community and Clinical Data for Augmenting Influenza Modeling

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EAGER represents timely and essential exploratory work assessing the value of community-sourced data in infectious disease modeling efforts. Community-generated data can suffer from lack of information about the reference population, which hinders prevalence estimates. In theory, real-time and near real-time community-sourced data has been recognized to offer important opportunity to improve timeliness and scope of infectious disease modeling efforts, but there are still fundamental questions regarding the value of community infection data for understanding, monitoring and forecasting. Towards this, work here will study how community and clinically generated data compare regarding measures of disease incidence, contributing population demographics, and spatio-temporal coverage in influenza dynamics. Public dissemination of our research and findings will help expose and educate the community in data generation and forecasting efforts.

This project involves a rigorous and systematic comparison between contemporaneous community and clinical data on acute respiratory infections. The goal of this work will be to first generate a diverse community-sourced data set with a defined reference population. We will then assess significance of outcomes between groups in community and clinical data, accounting for demographic and epidemiological factors. Dynamical modeling and Bayesian inference methods will be used to develop and augment disease forecasts. Normalized and municipal scale estimates from the community samples will be integrated and the data generation and modeling efforts will together be used to assess the impact of community data on real-time and near-real time simulations and forecasts. The high-risk work can potentially be paradigm shifting regarding how we collect and use data in forecasting methods for disease as well as a broader range of societal issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project were to assess:  (1) How community and clinically generated data compare regarding disease incidence, contributing population demographics, and spatio-temporal coverage; and (2) The value of community infection data for understanding, monitoring and forecasting seasonal and pandemic influenza dynamics.

 

The intellectual merit contributions of this project included advancing scientific understanding of how and when community-sourced data can be useful in infectious disease forecasting and other modeling efforts. To examine how predictive community-sourced data is compared to other data collected via other ways (e.g. clinically), we implemented appropriate analytic methods for comparing data even if it represents different constituent populations and showed how community-generated data can give timely information on health seeking behavior during an outbreak. As well, through a systematic analysis of data gathered via these different modalities, we illustrated characteristics of the surveillance approach (data collection method, survey questions, the places/groups and time periods data is collected from) for whichpredictive performance of the same symptom combinations for infection can vary. Through identifying traits that can modulate data from different sources, we generated recommendations for researchers and practitioners that want to use parallel data streams, and specific steps that researchers and practitioners should take proactively when creating or using new datasets to improve infectious disease forecasts. As well, we developed a machine learning method for improving domain adaptation across data collected from different modalities, given varying population demographics of the underlying populations in different data sets. 

 

Broader Impacts of this project are at multiple levels. Dissemination of findings to diverse scientific communities (computer science/machine learning and infectious disease/public health and medical communities) via publications and presentations has exposed communities to the opportunities of interdisciplinary work and specifically benefits in augmenting infectious disease forecasting. Talks given by PI Chunara and graduate students at conferences, and department seminars have also been attended by undergraduate and graduate students (amongst faculty and industry members) and provided exposure to those in computer science, statistics and bioinformatics to potential applications of their research. Finally, the focus on community-generated data means that members of the public have also been informed about the research, and opportunities of data in health broadly, via their involvement in the data generating process and materials and public outreach events that have been part of the research process.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2019
Modified by: Rumi Chunara

The intellectual merit contributions of this project included advancing scientific understanding of how and when community-sourced data can be useful in infectious disease forecasting and other modeling efforts. To examine how predictive community-sourced data is compared to other data collected via other ways (e.g. clinically), we implemented appropriate analytic methods for comparing data even if it represents different constituent populations and showed how community-generated data can give timely information on health seeking behavior during an outbreak. As well, through a systematic analysis of data gathered via these different modalities, we illustrated characteristics of the surveillance approach (data collection method, survey questions, the places/groups and time periods data is collected from) for whichpredictive performance of the same symptom combinations for infection can vary. Through identifying traits that can modulate data from different sources, we generated recommendations for researchers and practitioners that want to use parallel data streams, and specific steps that researchers and practitioners should take proactively when creating or using new datasets to improve infectious disease forecasts. As well, we developed a machine learning method for improving domain adaptation across data collected from different modalities, given varying population demographics of the underlying populations in different data sets. Broader Impacts of this project are at multiple levels. Dissemination of findings to diverse scientific communities (computer science/machine learning and infectious disease/public health and medical communities) via publications and presentations has exposed communities to the opportunities of interdisciplinary work and specifically benefits in augmenting infectious disease forecasting.
